div.head: Question 23
Whether quality admits of a greater or lesser degree
div.p: Whether quality admits of a greater or lesser degree.

I respond that this proposition should be distinguished according to the composed and divided sense. The composite sense is impossible because no quality takes a greater and lesser at the same time. The divided sense is true and this is with respect to the logic of the question. With respect the matter he puts that color has some latitude Nevertheless, that color has latitude is able to be understood in two ways.

In one mode thus that it does not really have distinct intermediates, just as is true about time and motion because an hour and a year are not really distinguished just as Socrates in the forum and Socrates in the theater are not really distinguished. But when it is said that time has parts, one of which is day and another is year or hour, these propositions ought to be understood thus, hour is part of day and this thing, as it is an hour, lasts less than an a day or a year. Or it is able to be explained thus, the following proposition is true longer in this region the heavens are day than this proposition in the same region the heavens are now in the ninth hour. And in this way it should be conceded that time has intermediaries. And then not in another sense unless this: the heavens, as it is hour, does not thus last longer, just as the heavens, as it is a year or double time to a year or an hour. And it is in the same way concerning the latitude of heat, for the same thing is the latitude of heat and heat. And the latitude of heat has parts, just as time because the same heat, as it is in the process of changing is called 'latitude', and when it is changed is called heat and not latitude.
In another mode, having really distinct intermediaries could be to be conceded or be understood intensively, and this sense beckons and denies.

In a third mode, it is possible for having distinct intermediaries to be understood extensively according to the intermediaries of the subject, and thus he concedes that both time and motion have really distinct intermediaries, just the heavens themselves have because there is not a latitude except the heat itself.

I respond to the first argument that, if fire in the highest degree ought to generate from water fire in the highest degree, it should not be imagined that continuously in the beginning of the action of fire the latitude of heat is led into water. Rather there is a successive corruption of the water. and it does not lead some heat of fire nor the form of fire before an ultimate instant of corruption of water, and then immediately will lead to the highest fire and highest color.

Again, in solving the second principale argument, where he inquires, whether contraries at the same time are coextended in the same subject, he holds that this is not so on account of many arguments, saying that, when fire is generated from water, it should not be imagined it is immediately corrupted and then fire would be generated and intended successively, nor that through the intermediary of time in which the matter of water will be changed is the whole water successively corrupted, and in another intermediary the form of fire. Rather water is successively corrupted and the form of fire and its heat will be immediately generated such that it is that heat is not generated before the entire cold is corrupted, nevertheless this heat through which water is called hot is the same thing with the coldness of water, and coldness removed from water is accidental heat. Whence there are not hot things of the same species because accidental heat of water is of a different species than the heat of fire and of the sames species with the cold of water, and therefore water made hot returns to coldness without an extrinsic agent. Whence properly it does not change itself because alteration is properly is a remission of a form contrary to the form of the agent. Whence this hotness, when it becomes weaker does not remit hotness but is intended, and the reason is because this hotness is essentially coldness and accidentally hot.

Against, according to the same person, corruption of a natural thing is not contrary to its generation through the same degrees, but generation of fire from water will be from the contrary corruption of the form of water and its coldness, and the generation of water from that will be from successive corruption in the latitude of fire and its hotness, and water its coldness will immediately be generated, and this it is saved what is accept the first instant of a permanent thing in being and thus the last, and the quality of motion is denoted from a prior passion according to the imagination of the Commentator in book 8 of the Physics, in comment 69. However, that heat in water is essentially coldness, he proves thus, through a sign because heat in water remits hotness equally when causing with water. But the consequence is not because some hotness would remit the hotness of the same species.

But if is said that, if hotness in water is essentially coldness, why does it not represent the feeling of coldness but instead the feeling of hotness? He responds that, just as white posited by something removed through a removed intension represents blackness to sight or to the corporal medium, so the coldness of water significantly remitted represents hotness.

Note that the same heat is able to be more intense than it already is without the addition of another because suppose God makes two intermediaries of a heat coextending at the same time in the same place, therefore it is twice as intense as before. But he does not argue against this because in this way the heat of Christ will be more intense than the heat of some other because his intermediary is in the same place the intermediary of the others, and thus into infinity. It is said that this is not to the proposed because the heat of Christ in the sacrament is not there locally nor situationally, therefore etc.
